questions.explanation: Linearity: F{ax(t)+by(t)} = aX(ω)+bY(ω). Scaling and addition pass through unchanged. This is the foundation property that makes Fourier analysis useful for superposition.
Time reversal flips the spectrum: F{x(-t)} = X(-ω). Playing a signal backwards reverses its frequency characteristics. For real signals, this means conjugation since X(-ω) = X*(ω).

questions.prompt: Time scaling x(at) with a>1 causes frequency to:
questions.explanation: F{x(at)} = (1/|a|)X(ω/a). Compressing time (a>1) expands frequency by 1/a. Fast signals have wide bandwidth. This is the uncertainty principle: you can't have narrow time AND narrow frequency.

questions.prompt: Duality: if F{x(t)} = X(ω), then F{X(t)} =:
questions.explanation: Duality property: swapping roles of t and ω gives F{X(t)} = 2πx(-ω). This lets us find new transform pairs from known ones. The 2π factor comes from the synthesis integral.

questions.prompt: If x(t) is real and even, X(ω) is:
questions.explanation: Real-even signals have real-even transforms. The integral of (even)×cos(ωt) is real; the integral of (even)×sin(ωt) is zero. No imaginary part. Symmetric x means symmetric X.

questions.prompt: If x(t) is real and odd, X(ω) is:
questions.explanation: Real-odd signals give purely imaginary, odd transforms. The cosine integral is zero (odd×even = odd); the sine integral is real and odd, making X purely imaginary and odd.

questions.prompt: Multiplication x(t)y(t) in time corresponds to:
questions.explanation: Multiplication theorem: F{x·y} = (1/2π)X*Y. Time multiplication = frequency convolution. This is dual to convolution theorem. Used for analyzing modulated signals.
Integration divides by jω but needs DC handling: F{∫x} = X(ω)/(jω) + πX(0)δ(ω). The delta term accounts for any DC in the integral. Low frequencies are amplified.

questions.prompt: The initial value x(0) relates to:
questions.explanation: From the inverse Fourier transform at t=0: x(0) = (1/2π)∫X(ω)dω. All frequency components add up at t=0. This connects time-domain value to total area under the spectrum.
At ω=0, X(0) = ∫x(t)·1·dt = ∫x(t)dt. The DC component equals the total area (net integral) of the signal. Zero-mean signals have X(0)=0.
